Designed with Thingiverse user Spauda01 of D-Bot printer fame: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065 This design is for ROBO3D owners who upgraded their hot end to the E3D V6 and then realized that the two screws in the heatsink top does not secure the hot end properly. Before this clamp design I went through 3 heat sinks since they would all grind out on top from the screws. This will lower the hot end assembly height slightly. You may need a longer PTFE tube for easier filament insertion as well as adjusting your z offset slightly. My z offset with this clamp installed is -1.
  • Use the existing screws in the X axis assembly to attach the larger half of the clamp to the bottom of the X axis assembly.
  • Use 2 M3 25 mm bolts and 2 M3 nuts to then attach smaller half of clamp around the top of heat sink to larger half.

description.text: I wanted to have my pliers up on edge so they could better fit in my toolbox, and after looking at commercial options such as http://www.amazon.ca/Lisle-40460-Black-Pliers-Wrench/dp/B00AC60ZZ2/ref=sr_1_fkmr1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1456501385&sr=8-3-fkmr1&keywords=lisle+wrench+organizer I decided to create this. The issue with the linked item is that if you have pliers with large grips like I do, only the 3 bigger slots will work, the others are too narrow. I measured my 20+ pairs of pliers and attempted to create something that would work for most of them. The only pairs I cant accommodate are angled needle nose pliers, as they just dont like to be stood on edge no matter what I do. I've included the solidworks files if you want to adjust the widths of the slots to work with your tools. I will update this shortly with a photo of it in action.

Introduction It was quite tricky. Because I'm using the FreeCAD which hasn't got tool for adding a numbers or text, so it was a chalenge little bit. I would like to design it only in free & open source applications - to show that it is possible! Solution There is very nice and easy for beginners QCAD application which is a free and open source. QCAD works on Windows, Mac OS X and Linux and for the 2D it's perfect! Steps
  • draw the circle in QCAD, check diameter
  • divide the circle into equal segments - pizza slices :)
  • add text, for example 1/8 at only one part
  • delete rest of the circle parts - we need just one
  • export it as svg file and close QCAD
  • open FreeCAD
  • import the shape and expand it into a 3D solid

Objectives Depending from the age of students and their knowledge,
  • explain what a fraction is
  • explain when we're using fractions in real life - pizza example
  • describe fraction, numerator, denominator, fraction bar, unit fraction, and multiple
  • identify the number of shaded parts and the number of equals parts in a circle shape
  • explain how to write a fraction using mathematical notation and using words
  • explain how to add, divide, substract, change denominators in fractions
  • when you think of a fractions, think of a PIZZA!!
    • Audiences Pupils age - depending from the country and the pupils knowledge level. Mostly for primary school or earlier. Preparation If the teacher explains fractions for the bigger group 1 printed kit is enough, but for the work in smaller groups it will be necessary to print more than 1 kit. Steps

• Lesson 1 fraction
    • What is it? How to write a fraction using mathematical notation?
    How to describe it using words. Using fractions in real life.
  • Lesson 2 comparing fractions
    • Which fraction is bigger? How many pieces are equal to 1. How many of 1/8 are equal to 1/2? Determine if two fractions are equivalent.
  • Lesson 3 definitions
    • Describe fraction, numerator, denominator, fraction bar, unit fraction, multiple, proper fraction, improper fraction, mixed number.
  • Lesson 4 mathematical operations
    • Explain how to add, divide, substract or multiple fractions.
    Addition - same denominators
    Substraction - same denominators
    Division / multiplication
    Changing denominators
    Convert a fraction to an equivalent fraction with a specified denominator Results At the end of this project, students should have a fractions knowledge.
    How to add, divide, substract or to change denominators or just how to split pizza for 8 persons or to 3 :)

description.text:
CR-7 use M5 thread rod for z step. Maybe you want to change it to lead screw.
如果你想把CR7從牙條改成螺桿(絲桿)，你可以這樣做： What I do:
1.Buy lead screw, you need to know it's step.
2.Reaming the hole, suggest 10 mm
3.Get the CR-7 firmware
4.print this adapter 1.買螺桿
2.擴孔，你可用電鑽、電磨(電磨筆、電磨機)
3.取得韌體，這私下問我
4.印這個轉接座 Benefit of this adapter:
我這個轉接座的特點呢：
第一個是他不像allen原本設計的，需要切掉法蘭，所以四個螺絲都可以鎖上。
其次，他也比社團內設計的短一點，越長就越可能晃動
然後，雖然我設計的時後可以讓躺平列印，但是這樣軸心就可能偏掉。我還是建議直立列印。原本allen設計沒有斜面，直印不好印。

The mk7 is a marvel of simplicity but I'm still partial to ball bearing idler extruders.
I just don't love having that delrin plunger dragging on the filament and I like to be able to quickly release the tension so that you can pull the filament out and replace it easily without having to run the stepper.

6/26/12 - I just uploaded a new experimental version with a recess for a nut for the tensioner. I haven't printed it as I'm out of town at the moment but feel free to give it a try. It's called mk7-lever-drive-tension-nut.stl (It should be the last file). The lever is unchanged. Either print out the parts separately or print out one of the plates (with or without the quick release). Remove the support from the lever (where the bearing goes, it's just two thin walled cylinders)
Remove the support from the underside of the body.
Remove the support from the quick release (two cylinders again) If you have a 3mm tap, you might as well run it through the holes for the tensioner and the bearing. Install a 623 (or R2) bearing (3mmx10mmx4mm) in the arm with an 3mm x 10mm countersunk screw
Put the pin for the quick release in the quick release and install the screw (3mm x 20mm)
Snap the lever onto the drive and install the tensioner screw or quick release. Install the drive the same way you would the normal mk7 block. Tighten the tensioner screw until the stepper misses steps when you hold onto the filament (as opposed to just slipping).

comments.text: is there any way to make this work with a 608 bearing, the kind that skateboards use?
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: Not really, Â a 608 bearing is half the width of the stepper so, it would need to be a much bigger assembly. Â The mark 5/6 filament feeders could be tweaked for a 608 but they use a different hot end.

title: Elf Rangers (28mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A couple of elf rangers for your tabletop gaming enjoyment! DLP methods should yield some good results, though if you're a proficient printer who consistently gets support material to work for you, go for it, and POST PICS! I want to see this guy printed. For anyone browsing this that wants the models but doesn't have access to a printer, 3D Hubs printsfolk might be able to do that for you (just click the link to the side) or you can get a pretty affordable print from Shapeways here. This character was modeled as a commission for a customer and is also useful in our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics, along with any other game that uses heroic scale models. For an 18mm version, this guy should work nicely. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

description.text: As a 3D printer owner, the two most important elements for 3D printings are the 3D printer itself and the printing elements...Filaments. I've used only PLA for most of my printed objects. I know there are many other materials other printers use, but for me, PLA is economical and is good enough for my design needs. However, in order to keep the PLA filament in its optimal conditions, you have to keep it in a moisture-free container. So after doing many researches, including here on Thingverse, I have come up with my own low-budget Filament Storage Box design, which will not only store my filaments in the near moisture-free box, and I can also keep the filament in the box while making the prints. You can download all the required components here, and I've also posted links on the two key components you can get them yourself. Please let me know if you have any questions and suggestions about my design...Thanks... ^_^ Sterlite 20Qt. Gasket Box - http://www.target.com/p/sterilite-20-qt-air-tight-storage-tote-transparent-with-blue-latch/-/A-15066036?lnk=rec|pdp|related_prods_vv|pdpv1 Eva-Dry E-500 Dehumidifier - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000H0XFD2?keywords=eva-dry%20e500&qid=1456505807&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1

description.header: !Notice! I'm still working on this one, so expect updates/improvements in the next few days!
This is a set for taking a spore print from a single mushroom.
description.text:
To make a spore print:
Clean the acrylic plates with alcohol and dry them well with a clean cloth or paper. Clean your table surface too. Take a fresh (right after picking) matured mushroom, and remove the stem. Place it with the gills or pores facing down on the acrylic plate. Place and leave it in a clean and dry place with little to no air circulation. After about 12 hours, remove the mushroom. You will see a 'print' of the mushroom gill/pore pattern, made my thousands upon thousands of spores. Depending on the species, the color of the print can vary from white, purple to black. Lay the second arcylic plate on top, and press them together slightly. The spores are now sandwiched between the two plates, so no dust/dirt/microbes can enter. Press them joined together into the 3D printed wrapper, and then place on the 3D printed cap. In the fridge or freezer, you keep a spore print viable for a few months up to a few years. More:
These instructions have been published in my blog with pictures, check it out here: (link coming) Coming soon: How to make a liquid culture with your print: (link coming) About the files: The size is 100x100mm, which should be enough for most mushrooms. Feel free to get the .3dm (Rhino) , .stp (Solidworks / Dassault) or .skp (Sketchup) and change the size according to your needs. To use this, have the 3mm acrylic sheet (.dxf file) laser cut, and print the two pieces.

The abacus is a fundamental tool for learning to count.
the use of this tool facilitates and speeds the learning of simple numerical calculation, in fact it is used in primary schools to practice and get in contact with the abstract world of mathematics.
  • My passion for 3D printing was born at Rome Maker Faire. I made lots of drawings and I studied well the characteristics of 3d printing in all its stages. I have many projects ready to be printed, but I can't afford to buy or build a printer. I hopethat by partecipating in this competition, I can finally give life to my project. It's my childhood dream. Thanks! -

Printer:

None

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

30

Notes: Only the lid needs supports and you can modify infill if you want.

The components have been designed in tolerance so that they aren't necessary post processing actions.
You can color the letters with permanent markers.

The abacus was designed in Inventor.
Everything has been designed to be compact and it closes ina a box.
The rods are square so that the cubes don't rotate.
The lid is divided so as to separete the cubes for color where not used.
The base have a housing for the lid.

Objectives this simple tool facilitates learning the calculations to children and it's compact, simple to use and in the form. Audiences The use of this instrument is dedicated to primary school children and their teachers that can use as a medium of learning.
Moreover the children will approach to the fantastic world of 3d printing. Preparation Printing and play! Step 1 Printing the base, I reccomend you to do the base white so that later you can color the letters: U-blue, DA-red, H-green and K-violet. Step 2 Printing the 4 rods and then put the glue on the seat base to fix them. Step 3 Printing the cubes.
There are 10 cubes for each colorsn so you need blue, red, green and violet filament or you can color them in other ways.
You can reduce the infill for them. Step 4 Printing the lid.
You can rotate it in the way to not generate supports but it's higher. Results Students can take advantage of this tool plus interchangeable and customizable with their own name.
Mathematics will be easier to understand and more fun to learn.
3d printer will enter into their lives so that right now they can exploit its potential to have fun but also to make it a passion.

This is a project I've been needing for a long time.  When I use my CNC router table I would just layout my cutting tools.  Most of the time they would roll around or fall on the floor. With the tool holder I place all of my tools, collets, and I can place the tools I need in the order I will need them in.  This is the first step.  The second step is to make an arm and attach it to the computer stand down tube.

I made this out of plastic wood but almost anything will work. The material is an 1" thick and all the holes are 3/4" deep.  The pocket is 1/2" deep.  I included the CAM file for MACH3 (use at own risk not libel for broken tools, works on my mill)

title: Prusa-Belt 624 X-Carriage for Mendel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing has been updated 25/6/12, use upper section 1.3. The 1.2 files are missing because I forgot to update while experimenting before moving out of my last flat (sorry), but 1.3 is now much easier to get wide-PEEK-block style extruders through fully assembled since I ruthlessly cut away unnecessary plastic.
I designed this so that I could more easily use a Prusa-style belt setup while using the original 624 bearings on my Sells Mendel x-carriage.
PLA bushings just seem to have too much friction to me, and linear bearings can't be put on or taken off the X-axis without removing the smooth bars from the end brackets. (Not to mention the extra expense just to try that out).
By making the space for a tool head or hot end to fit through rounder, instead of the old long-narrow shape (on left for comparison), this allows you to mount a tool at either 90 degree angle, like the Prusa x-carriage. I also put holes on the side to mount a 40mm or 32mm PC north-bridge fan to cool any plastic extruder filament drive.
The bottom part has now been updated so there should be enough room to fit a standard mendel hot-end in there at the 30 degrees angle that greg's hinged extruder mounts it. In my case I simply took the original lower section of my mendel x-carriage, snapped off the part that used to support belt clamp bolts, and cut away some material from the bottom. My models were quickly based on Idaholion's solidworks models of Mendel parts (picture of original for comparison), so I had to rotate the STL files in blender after exporting them (you will find the STEP files are at a silly 90deg orientation.
I also noticed when I went to upload the updated files that I had previously posted the wrong .blend file from a different thing, derp. I can't believe the 16 people who downloaded it by then didn't tell me though :P

Assemble as per the instructions for the original Sells Mendel X-Axis: http://reprap.org/wiki/Mendel_X-axis
...with the exception of the belt clamps, which no longer protrude bolts into your hot-end space. For these you can use standard Prusa clamps on the protruding side of the top, or use the included adjustable belt clamps by facing captive nuts inwards then swinging your belt-ends over the top and back under each clamp, to tighten them up with an M3 bolt after fixing the ends in place.
Also you may need to use more appropriately-sized M4 bolts than those ones facing diagonally upwards in the original design (I already do), so that they don't collide with the top part.

comments.text: I just upgraded my standard mendel X carriage to the open-x carriage and am very impressed with it - you should consider that as an option.
comments.author: Lenbok

comments.text: Yeah I saw it ages ago, though I'm not sure about buback's method of clamping the belt with printed teeth, that's the main sticking point for me, having had trouble with backlash whenever the belt got slack before.
comments.author: Lenbok

Just wanted to share my Acetone Vapor Bath setup. The glass container has a 4.25" mouth opening which a standard coffee mug top fits through easily. I merely pried the metal rim off of a portable coffee mug top to be used as a rest at the bottom. To keep it centered, I drilled 4 holes on the sides and threaded bolts with nuts though them. Once inside the jar, the bolts are turned until they each hit the sides of the jar. For the basket, I found a metal food skimmer, removed the plastic handle and bent the loops upwards. I squished the mesh (which allows the acetone to smooth the bottom as well) until it formed somewhat of a flat surface for the prints to sit on. I then took some wire and looped it in and around the loops while making sure the top of the wire would fit inside the jar. Next came the lid... I decided to design it to keep as much of the vapor inside while having a safety feature that wouldn't allow pressure to build up. Hence the safety BB and Mini Clothespin pressure valve was born.
I took a mini clothespin and drilled a small hole on both sides of the contacts making sure that they weren't too deep. When the BB is inside, the wood doesn't touch which ensures that pressure is on the BB. I then attached the clothespin to the top of the lid with some superglue. Once it was solidly bonded, I drilled a smaller hole through the center of the hole in which the BB sits. To make sure the clothespin had a good seal and won't break off, I hot glued around its base. When pressure builds, the BB allows the pressure to be released rather than having it blow the lid off. This keeps the majority of the vapors inside where we want them to stay and helps prevent the Acetone from evaporating.
  • I noticed people are trying to download this project... all you'll get is a slab with a photo of the jar grouped to it... figured I'd save you the time and effort.

comments.text:
I had thoughts of making a vapor bath chamber from one of my old printer chassis - I figure they are doing little good otherwise :).
My idea is to add a vapor capture/charcoal filter to it (well apply the one I had on that chassis) and use the old heated bed.
The challenge I have (aside from time to do it) is that I have no idea of how I can know how long is long enough without watching it.

comments.author: GeekDoc

comments.text: A majority of people with 3D printers have the heated print bed which is quite useful not only for printing but also for acetone smoothing. The bed has a temperature control built in. You place a small amount of the acetone into the container (about a teaspoon or so) without the basket in it and put the jar onto the printer bed. Place the item you wish to smooth into the container via the basket and put the lid on. Heat the bed up to around 90-100C (I use 90) and let sit for some time (depends on how large the item is, how smooth you want it, etc). I've been sticking with a 10-15 minute smoothing process with most of my projects.

description.text: This was one of our rewards from our Kickstarter campaign for Wayfarer Tactics (thank you to our amazing backers!) and I thought it would be a fun one to release, even though most machines are going to have trouble with this. DLP methods should yield some good results, though if you're a proficient printer who consistently gets support material to work for you, go for it, and POST PICS! I want to see this guy printed. For anyone browsing this that wants the model but doesn't have access to a printer, 3D Hubs printsfolk might be able to do that for you (just click the link to the side) or you can get a pretty affordable (especially considering the size) print from Shapeways here. (I would advise the White Polished and Flexible option). This character was modeled for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics. We'll make an 18mm version available soon. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: Blistoid
remixed_from.title: Calculus project 1: Volume of a container

description.text:
This is the third part of a series of projects intended for first year calculus students. In this series, students will learn how to use different mathematical equations to assess the properties of solids and containers.
In this part, we will be using our molds we created in part two to create permanent castes to use later on in the project. To do this we will learn how to make our very own, cheap, silicone casting substrate.

Printer:

CraftBot

Supports:

No

Resolution:

optimum

Infill:

30% square

Notes: I optimized this thing to be printed in ABS with maximum settings. I would recommend a skirt with an offset of 0mm (otherwise known as a brim) with 2-5 loops for ABS. As can be seen from the photo, an increased infill may be helpful as well.

For this project I used a free program from Autodesk called TinkerCAD. I have long been a user of AutoCAD which is a desktop drafting program from the same company. I used TinkerCAD to make it easier for educators and learners to be able to more easily replicate what I did. TinkerCAD is awesome because it's not only free, but it's easy to use. It also runs in your browser and has built in instructional lessons.
www.tinkercad.com For part 3 of this project I started out with our product from the part 2. If you remember, we used X=20mm which gave us a base of 60x20mm, two flaps with dimensions of 60x20mm, and two flaps with dimensions of 20x20mm. We then made this into a mold by adding a channel around the base and extending the flaps.

Objective At the end of this part of the project, students will have a permanent mold of the volume that they will be using equations to find. Not only will this be a visual aid, but will help them to check the accuracy of what they are doing. Audience Even though the overall project is designed for Calculus students, this part of the project can be used for algebra or even art students as well. Preparation Teachers will need to get all supplies ahead of time:

  • 100% Silicone caulking
    Cost: $3-$5
    Caulking is available in all types and brands, but what you need is simply 100% Silicone caulking. Any brand will do, so buy whatever is on sale. The white kind is better than clear, as it's easier to tell when it's thoroughly mixed. This forms the bulk of your mold. Get a caulking gun too, if you don't have one already.

  • Plastic Cups, Silverware, and Straws
    Cost: $3-$5
    The silicone won't stick to the cup after it's cured, and you can throw it away when you're done. The straws are helpful if you don't have any pipettes or eyedroppers.

  • Corn Starch
    Cost: $2-$4
    The cornstarch is essential to this. It will absorb the moisture in the mix and allow it to dry throughout.
    • Step 1: Add ingredients Your ratio determines how long your cure time is. A ration of 1:1 should give you about 5-10 minutes cure time. This should be about right for this project. You will want your mixture to be about the consistency of cake frosting when it is all mixed together. Step 2: Mix It is important that you mix it thoroughly. If you don't then the caste will not dry evenly and in extreme cases cold cause it to crack. Step 3: Pour Use what ever item (silverware, pipettes, etc...) you have to spoon/pour your material out with. Make sure it is even with the top of the mold. You can use a flat object (such as the back of a knife) to run along the top of the mold and wick away the excess. Step 4: Let dry Parts this small should be dry in 1-2 hours. This caste was made using kinetic sand Results The students will now have a cheap, hands on way of making a caste of the volume they will be using equations to find, This will give them a visual and tactile way of understanding what they are doing. This will also give them a way to check their work, shown in the next part of this project.

remixed_from.title: Kossel Effector E3D V6 Bowden 1.75mm (Includ autoprobing)

title: Mini Kossel E3D V6 Effector & 30mm Duct fan

description.text:
This is my remix of various part to make what IMHO is the best compromise.
One of the challenge with a Mini Kossel is the size of the effector and effectively making sure anything that you add to it, do not or least doesn't reduce the build volume too much as anything added to the side will get caught by the belt when printing near the edge of the build volume. The other little things is the E3D V6 is a longer hotend than alternative. I wanted an effector that allow me to mount the hotend without loosing build height and PontPont design kind of did it well by moving the clamp above the effector. Share the love submit your make :-)

The change to PontPont design include.

  • removing the probe thingy sorry I'm old school and I manually calibrate my delta and just don't trust that time wasting routine at the beginning of the print.

  • reduce the height of the effector and clamp by 1mm to allow easiest access to fit the Bowden tube clip by Walter

  • Added a hole to fit a screw to hold the fan shroud in place

The change to joshuarowley42 design include
  • I've added a small 1mm leap to the bottom of the duct. 1) to make is a bit stronger when printed and 2) To fit the original fan duct on the new effector the easiest is to turn it upside down to make sure airflow cover as much of the heatsink as possible
  • I've added a little 3mm hole and the recess for a M3 nuts that align with the hole of the effector. The press fit design was great but when you print the duct it's not always easy to get it right, a kossel effector can move and jerk fast and as the 2 extras fan mounted will create a bit more weight I thought it will be safer to have a screw holding the duct in place
    • The V6.6_Duct_v1.stl is added for references in case anyone want to use it standalone The change to RAYMONDHOPK include
  • Duplicated and mirrored the original duct to allow a fan on each side
  • Grouped the e3d duct with the 2 cooling duct
  • Cut a bit from the bottom of the duct
    • The e3d_v6_duct_fan.stl is for viewing purpose only to demonstrate how the duct fit around the hotend

Printer:

Prusa I3 extended / Mini Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

40

Notes: Cooling is strong enough for those to be made in PLA if you want no melting will occur. It can be printed without support if your print is well calibrated. The print settings are not mandatory

Force fit M3 screw I usually thread the fan screw with a electric screwdriver it's much easier. Just be gentle when you do it. Parts 15 X M3 16mm (or 14) socket or machine screw work but button head have a smallest profile and better for the fan
12 for the fan
1 to hold the duct fan to the effector
2 for the hotend clamp 3 X 30mm fan E3D fan are the best out there

description.text:
This is the fourth part of a series of projects intended for first year calculus students. In this series, students will learn how to use different mathematical equations to assess the properties of solids and containers. In this part we will be using the castes made from part 3 to check the work we accomplished in part 1. Part1:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1368258 Part 3:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1373188

Printer:

CraftBot

No

No

optimum

30% square

Notes: I optimized this thing to be printed in ABS with maximum settings. I would recommend a skirt with an offset of 0mm (otherwise known as a brim) with 2-5 loops for ABS. I would also suggest an increased infill ratio.

For this project I used a free program from Autodesk called TinkerCAD. I have long been a user of AutoCAD which is a desktop drafting program from the same company. I used TinkerCAD to make it easier for educators and learners to be able to more easily replicate what I did. TinkerCAD is awesome because it's not only free, but it's easy to use. It also runs in your browser and has built in instructional lessons.
www.tinkercad.com For part 4 of this project I started out with our product from the part 2. If you remember, we used X=20mm which gave us a base of 60x20mm, two flaps with dimensions of 60x20mm, and two flaps with dimensions of 20x20mm. We then made this into a mold by adding a channel around the base and extending the flaps.
Part 2:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1371700

description.header: Project: Using submersion to find volume
description.text:
Objective At the end of this part of the project students will be able to test/prove the math that they used in part 1 of this project. Audience Even though the overall project is designed for Calculus students, this part of the project can be used for algebra students as well. Preparation
  • Teachers will need to make sure they have access to graduated cylinders with mL/MM3 markings.
  • Teachers will have needed to complete all other steps of this project already, preferably with their class
    • Step 1: Setup graduated cylinders Place graduated cylinders on a table visible to all students. Add just enough water so the castes from part 3 can be submersed. Step 2: Record water level Make sure you record where the water level is BEFORE you submerse any castes, and in-between submersing each one. Step 3: Submerse castes Submerse the castes that you created in part 3, one at a time. Step 4: Calculate volume To find V, you must take the water level before submersion, and subtract it from the water level after submersion. Step 5: Compare Compare the volumes that you recorded from this part to the numbers that you calculated from part 1. If all goes well, your numbers should match up pretty well. Results Students now have gone from creating a lidless box, to calculating it's formula, and now even to proofing that their formula works. Now they are ready for part 5; charting their data!

Here is 5cm x 5cm x 5cm underbin for the under shelf rails.

The Pirate Ship Pencil Holder is an excellent decoration for a pirate themed classroom or an oceanography class. This decoration features the holes the pencils fit in, the pirate ship and the base wave that the ship rides on.

Printer:

other

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

How I Designed This: To make this, you first have to make the base of the ship using a rectangular prism, then you use the triangular prism to make the keel of the ship. Next, you use the shapes you see to make the ship. To make the wave, you get a rectangular prism and add a half cylinder to the front and group them together. Then you use hole cylinders to make the pencil slots. Project: Pirate Ship Pencil Holder
Objectives: Students would learn to be able to make simple yet fun ways to organize their desks and utilize different ways to make fun and easy objects. Audiences: You will need to be in at least sixth grade to have done this project, or if you have more experience than you should be able to do this project in lower level grades. Preparation: To be able to make this project you should have at least gone through some basic skills such as how to align objects and turn them into holes. Steps: The first step in making this project is to make the base and the wave. To make this step, You first have to get a blue rectangular prism and extend it to the size you prefer. Next you need a half cylinder (same color) and lengthen it to make it half the length of the rectangular prism. Then you put the half cylinder on top of the rectangular prism and align them so there is no overhang. The next step is to make the ship.To make the ship, you first have to make the base . To do this you just get a rectangular prism. Next you need to make the keel. To do this you use an upside down triangular prism, and make the base of the prism the same size as the base of the boat. Next you make the rails by using long and skinny rectangular prisms. The mast is made of cylinders that are tall and skinny and the sail is just flat rectangular prisms. To make the pencil holes, you first have to make a cylinder the size of the pencil hole you want, then you make it a hole and place it wherever you want on the boat. Then, once you make the shapes the colors you want them, you can group the objects and select multi color to complete the project. Results: At the end of the project, students should have designed a fully functional pirate ship pencil holder. Some ways to grade this could be based on object alignment and the correct look and use of the project.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jG467rz74Cm

Objectives By participating in this project, students learn how to incorporate shapes into real life tools. By making the cup holder, I learned how to use shapes to solve problems because I created a unique caterpillar that holds objects, and this creation helps to serve as an organizer. Audiences Any age could complete this project, and creating this project required little to no skill. Preparation To prepare for this project, completing the basic lessons is mandatory. Without completing the basic lessons on TinkerCad, the person creating the project will most likely be confused at first. Steps To design this, I just used a sphere and a cylinder. I turned the cylinder into a hole, and aligned it with the sphere and made sure the cylinder was just a little bit off of the workplane. I then grouped the two shapes to create the holder, and I duplicated the shape 7 times. I placed the duplicated shapes in a slight S shape to create the caterpillar’s body, and then made eyes using spheres. For the pupil, I flattened a sphere and placed it on a bigger sphere. I placed the eyes on the head of the body after grouping them, added flattened cubes for antennas, and grouped all of the objects together. Results The finished product looks exactly like the name says; it is a caterpillar cup holder.

comments.text:
Hello, please stop your postings. There is no art or sense behind mixing div. objects and call ist "art".
There are a lot of people all over the world who would like to provoke with there meanings like vegetarians or vegans.
But this is in my opinion no art. I think it's absolute ok to live his own style, but to "press" it in other peoples head
is like an act of agression. And please think about: if more then 50% of the people don't like your "art" you should stop it.
When more then 50% of the people like it you should go on.

title: Close up of a spider's "face" on a cylindrical STL file

description.text: This is close up of a spider's "face" on a cylindrical STL file. When you print it with a 3D printer you can put a light inside (usually small LED lights are best) to make a cylindrical lithophane. Made with PhotoToMesh.

author: oransen

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334355 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=334355

Using the following options: text_size = 7
text_font = Letters.dxf
text_allignment = embossed
text_itself = ldeaCasa
show_text = yes
Attached are the letters and symbols to create the slope-intercept formula (y=mx+b), as well as the rod to place them on and the plugs to connect the rods.
We made the letters and added holes in them for the rod to go through. Then, we made the rods.

Objectives: Students will learn the slope-intercept formula.
Audiences: Students taking Algebra 1 and above.
Preparation: No preparation needed.
Steps: We figured that many math teachers have trouble finding ways for their students to remember the formula. With our project, you place the letters and symbols on the rod and it will sit or hang in a classroom for all the students to see. You can easily put it out of sight for tests. The letters and symbols can be removed for students to have to place them in order on their own.
Results: You should print all letters and symbols used in the slope-intercept formula (y=mx+b) and the four rod pieces to place them on, along with the plugs to connect the rods in order for all to fit on them.

description.text: Great for Kids.

3d Files for the Camera Slider video posted by DIY PERKS (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GE37xI14Fyw). Please tip as all the tips go to a charitable cause! Frame mounts and camera mounts all included in files. Please let me know if you have edited it or made any cool edits. I will design a motor mount at a later stage for this as well for a rope powered system. Designed to be printed with PLA at 100% infill. (*_alt file)
Side Mounts include motor mount holes (if you want to add some level of automation) and the gap for the pulley/counterweight holder. C-Clamp holes not included. Will pop those in soon as I have some C-Clamps in hand.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100

comments.text:
I think it'd be nice to have the camera plate hinges modeled into those plates.
Using metal brackets and screwing them to the plates seems unnecessarily complex.
Could also model the filler plugs and caps, and some bushing spacers instead of stacks of washers.
comments.author: Muhalo

comments.text:
First of all, thanks for the great video and 3d models to make this camera slider.
I've uploaded a roller model that might be used instead of the one in your video description (couldn't get those shipped to my country).
Standard skateboard bearings fit, but I still have to test if they fit with the 22mm copper tubing.
Almost finished my build, but still waiting for some parts to arrive.
Roller -> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2073865
